Situation1: They occasionally give casual advice when asked about minor career choices.
Expectation2: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation2: A few machines are running hotter than normal after missing their last service window.
Story: I was halfway through my lunch when Jamie, one of the new hires, slid into the seat across from me. “Hey, do you think I should take that online course in automation?” she asked, eyes hopeful. I knew she’d been struggling to find her footing, and I wanted to help. I started to give her some advice, sharing what had worked for me when I was in her shoes. But as I spoke, my phone buzzed—an alert from the maintenance system. Three of the older machines were running hotter than normal, and I realized they’d missed their last service window. I was supposed to be on the floor, cleaning and checking them, making sure nothing failed. My supervisor had made it clear: machine downtime was unacceptable. Yet here I was, caught between being the mentor Jamie needed and the repairer the machines—and the company—depended on. I could see the expectation in Jamie’s face, waiting for my guidance, while the machines’ warning lights flashed in my mind. My stomach twisted as I tried to figure out which role I should answer first.
